content.raw:
Is there a big difference between using `==` vs. using a bitwise and `&`?
~~~
bool rightButton = (this->mouseEvent.button & common::MouseEvent::RIGHT);
~~~
So this is checking to see that only the right mouse button is pressed? That's probably right, but I'm just checking.
content.html:
Is there a big difference between using == vs. using a bitwise and &?

bool rightButton = (this->mouseEvent.button & common::MouseEvent::RIGHT);

So this is checking to see that only the right mouse button is pressed? That's probably right, but I'm just checking.

I haven't done much of bitwise operations, if that's preferred I can change it.

pullrequest.title: Select a link with the mouse if parent model already selected

content.raw: `GetRootVisual` gets the last parent before `__world_node__`. I *think* it is possible for a Visual to be without a parent if it gets detached, so I'll add checks to be sure.
content.html: GetRootVisual gets the last parent before __world_node__. I think it is possible for a Visual to be without a parent if it gets detached, so I'll add checks to be sure.

pullrequest.title: Select a link with the mouse if parent model already selected

content.raw: I think Steve means, as an alternative to `if (modelVis)`, you can instead do a `GZ_ASSERT` before something like `modelVis->GetHighlighted()` on line 704 (dereferencing pointer `modelVis`). I would say `GZ_ASSERT` is more appropriate if you don't expect `modelVis` to ever be NULL and want to assert to get thrown as an error condition, which may be the case here.
content.html: I think Steve means, as an alternative to if (modelVis), you can instead do a GZ_ASSERT before something like modelVis->GetHighlighted() on line 704 (dereferencing pointer modelVis). I would say GZ_ASSERT is more appropriate if you don't expect modelVis to ever be NULL and want to assert to get thrown as an error condition, which may be the case here.

pullrequest.title: Select a link with the mouse if parent model already selected

content.raw:
Asserts are not enabled for release builds. This means you can't replace an 'if' with an assert.

The theory is "Gazebo should never crash/shutdown unexpectedly". Asserts cause a program to end abruptly, so we need handle error conditions without using assert.
content.html:
Asserts are not enabled for release builds. This means you can't replace an 'if' with an assert.

The theory is "Gazebo should never crash/shutdown unexpectedly". Asserts cause a program to end abruptly, so we need handle error conditions without using assert.

pullrequest.title: Select a link with the mouse if parent model already selected

content.html:
So something along the lines of

if (!modelVis)
{
  gzerr << "Model visual not found, this should not happen" << std::endl;
  return;
}

pullrequest.title: Select a link with the mouse if parent model already selected

content.raw: So, you want to check how many links belong to the model associated with `modelVis`, correct? I think the "proper" way to get model information would be to query gzserver for model information, perhaps by subscribing to `/gazebo/default/model/info` (or `~/model/info`). Could be overkill though, especially if this is the only place in GLWidget where we need model information.
content.html: So, you want to check how many links belong to the model associated with modelVis, correct? I think the "proper" way to get model information would be to query gzserver for model information, perhaps by subscribing to /gazebo/default/model/info (or ~/model/info). Could be overkill though, especially if this is the only place in GLWidget where we need model information.

pullrequest.title: Select a link with the mouse if parent model already selected

content.raw: As far as I understand it, querying the server is time consuming... In the client-side, the place which could have this information is `ModelListWidget`, but I feel like this information must also be somewhere else already. Maybe each Visual could be assigned a `serverRole` or something like this, so we can figure out what it is.
content.html: As far as I understand it, querying the server is time consuming... In the client-side, the place which could have this information is ModelListWidget, but I feel like this information must also be somewhere else already. Maybe each Visual could be assigned a serverRole or something like this, so we can figure out what it is.

pullrequest.title: Select a link with the mouse if parent model already selected

content.raw: Right, GLWidget has access to a Scene pointer, which processes data from model/physics/sensor messages, but little to none of that data is publicly accessible.
content.html: Right, GLWidget has access to a Scene pointer, which processes data from model/physics/sensor messages, but little to none of that data is publicly accessible.

pullrequest.title: Select a link with the mouse if parent model already selected

content.raw:
I think that's a feasible approach. 

Brainstorming ideas here on possible ways to approach this:

- Add a function to Visual that allows you to set it's flag to indicate if it's a gui visual or not. You can probably call this function in Scene where you receive visual msgs.

- Quick workaround - check the visibility flag for `GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI`, `GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE`...etc to know that it's a gui visual
content.html:
I think that's a feasible approach.

Brainstorming ideas here on possible ways to approach this:

  • Add a function to Visual that allows you to set it's flag to indicate if it's a gui visual or not. You can probably call this function in Scene where you receive visual msgs.

  • Quick workaround - check the visibility flag for GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI, GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE...etc to know that it's a gui visual

pullrequest.title: Select a link with the mouse if parent model already selected

content.raw:
Ok, so I changed the logic to use visibility flags, bac0476.

In the process, fixed an issue with `Visual::GetVisibilityFlags` always returning `GZ_VISIBILITY_ALL` for visuals without attached objects. Following @iche033's suggestion, I stored the visibility flag value in a member variable.
content.html:
Ok, so I changed the logic to use visibility flags, bac0476.

In the process, fixed an issue with Visual::GetVisibilityFlags always returning GZ_VISIBILITY_ALL for visuals without attached objects. Following @iche033's suggestion, I stored the visibility flag value in a member variable.
